Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: A critical service is slowing under load and traces point to their recently merged functions
Story:
I stared at my phone, the group chat buzzing with excitement. My sister had just sent the itinerary for our family’s holiday trip, and Mom chimed in, “We really want you there this year.” I could almost hear her hopeful voice, and guilt pricked at me. I hadn’t made it to the last two celebrations, always blaming work. This time, I promised myself, I’d show up.

But my laptop screen glared back at me, lines of code taunting me with their complexity. The production service was buckling under load, and the traces pointed straight to the functions I’d merged yesterday. My team was counting on me to fix it—fast. If I didn’t, users would suffer, and my reputation as a reliable developer would take a hit. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in: my family’s longing for togetherness, my team’s need for my expertise. My heart raced as I tried to figure out how I could possibly be in two places at once, knowing that no matter what I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
